Let (Ωi,Fi,μi)i∈I(\Omega_i, \mathcal{F}_i, \mu_i)_{i \in I}(Ωi​,Fi​,μi​)i∈I​ be a family of σ\sigmaσ-finite measure spaces. Can one discuss the existence of a product measure on the infinite product space ∏i∈IΩi\prod_{i \in I} \Omega_i∏i∈I​Ωi​ with respect to the product σ\sigmaσ-algebra ⨂i∈IFi\bigotimes_{i \in I} \mathcal{F}_i⨂i∈I​Fi​ in the same way as when the index set I=NI = \mathbb{N}I=N?

I check some of the Mathlib code for Measure Theory and find that there seems not a definition about infinite product measure. So I may think the hardest part of formalization is about the proper definition of infinite product measure. I try a kind of formalization (not so mature).

Any suggestion is welcomed.

import Mathlib

open MeasureTheory
open scoped ENNReal

universe u v

section InfiniteProductMeasures

variable {I : Type u} (Ω : I → Type v)
  [∀ i, MeasurableSpace (Ω i)]
  (μ : ∀ i, Measure (Ω i)) [∀ i, SigmaFinite (μ i)]

/-! Basic Definitions -/

def ProdSpace := ∀ i, Ω i

instance : MeasurableSpace (ProdSpace Ω) :=
  ⨆ i, MeasurableSpace.comap (fun x : ProdSpace Ω => x i) inferInstance

structure FinCylinder where
  J : Finset I
  sets : ∀ i, Set (Ω i)
  sets_measurable : ∀ i, MeasurableSet (sets i)
  sets_full_outside : ∀ i ∉ J, sets i = Set.univ

def cylinderSet (C : FinCylinder Ω) : Set (ProdSpace Ω) :=
  {x | ∀ i, x i ∈ C.sets i}

noncomputable def cylinderMeasure (C : FinCylinder Ω) : ℝ≥0∞ :=
  ∏ i ∈ C.J, μ i (C.sets i)

-- Definition of "all but countably many are probability measures" condition
structure TailProbabilityCondition where
  J : Set I
  J_countable : Set.Countable J
  is_probability_outside : ∀ i ∉ J, μ i (Set.univ) = 1
  -- In fact, we need μ i to be probability measures, not just measure of whole space = 1
  is_probability_measure_outside : ∀ i ∉ J, IsProbabilityMeasure (μ i)

-- Condition: uncountably many factors have infinite total measure
structure UncountableInfiniteCondition where
  infinite_indices : Set I
  uncountable : ¬ Set.Countable infinite_indices
  has_infinite_measure : ∀ i ∈ infinite_indices, μ i (Set.univ) = ∞

/-!
Theorem 1: Countable index set case
When I is countable, a σ-finite product measure always exists
-/

theorem product_measure_exists_countable_index [Countable I] :
    ∃ (ν : Measure (ProdSpace Ω)),
      SigmaFinite ν ∧
      ∀ (C : FinCylinder Ω),
        ν {x : ProdSpace Ω | ∀ i, x i ∈ C.sets i} = ∏ i ∈ C.J, μ i (C.sets i) := by
  sorry

/-!
Theorem 2: Uncountable index set with "tail probability measure" condition
-/

theorem product_measure_exists_tail_probability
    (h : TailProbabilityCondition Ω μ) :
    ∃ (ν : Measure (ProdSpace Ω)),
      SigmaFinite ν ∧
      ∀ (C : FinCylinder Ω),
        ν {x : ProdSpace Ω | ∀ i, x i ∈ C.sets i} = ∏ i ∈ C.J, μ i (C.sets i) := by
  sorry

/-!
Theorem 3: Uncountable index set with uncountably many infinite-measure factors
This case is impossible
-/

theorem no_sigma_finite_product_uncountable_infinite
    (h : UncountableInfiniteCondition Ω μ) :
    ¬ ∃ (ν : Measure (ProdSpace Ω)),
        SigmaFinite ν ∧
        ∀ (C : FinCylinder Ω),
          ν {x : ProdSpace Ω | ∀ i, x i ∈ C.sets i} = ∏ i ∈ C.J, μ i (C.sets i) := by
  sorry

The construction proceeds by decomposing each σ\sigmaσ-finite measure μi\mu_iμi​ into a sum of finite measures μi=∑k=1∞μi(k)\mu_i = \sum_{k=1}^\infty \mu_i^{(k)}μi​=∑k=1∞​μi(k)​. Theorem 2 (Uncountable Index Set with Tail Probability Condition)  

For an uncountable index set III, a σ\sigmaσ-finite product measure exists if and only if there is a countable subset J⊂IJ \subset IJ⊂I such that μi\mu_iμi​ is σ\sigmaσ-finite for every i∈Ji \in Ji∈J and μi\mu_iμi​ is a probability measure (i.e., μi(Ωi)=1\mu_i(\Omega_i)=1μi​(Ωi​)=1) for every i∉Ji \notin Ji∈/J.  
Necessity. Assume a σ\sigmaσ-finite product measure ν\nuν exists. Write the product space as a countable union ∏iΩi=⋃n=1∞Bn\prod_i \Omega_i = \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty B_n∏i​Ωi​=⋃n=1∞​Bn​ with ν(Bn)<∞\nu(B_n) < \inftyν(Bn​)<∞. import Mathlib

open MeasureTheory

open scoped ENNReal

universe u v

section InfiniteProductMeasures

variable {I : Type u} (Ω : I → Type v)
  [∀ i, MeasurableSpace (Ω i)]
  (μ : ∀ i, Measure (Ω i)) [∀ i, SigmaFinite (μ i)]

/-! Basic Definitions -/

def ProdSpace := ∀ i, Ω i

instance : MeasurableSpace (ProdSpace Ω) :=
  ⨆ i, MeasurableSpace.comap (fun x : ProdSpace Ω => x i) inferInstance

structure FinCylinder where
  J : Finset I
  sets : ∀ i, Set (Ω i)
  sets_measurable : ∀ i, MeasurableSet (sets i)
  sets_full_outside : ∀ i ∉ J, sets i = Set.univ

/-!
Using Mathlib's existing definition of infinite product measure for probability measures
-/

-- Mathlib's definition requires probability measures
def IsProductProbabilityMeasure (ν : Measure (ProdSpace Ω)) : Prop :=
  ∀ (C : FinCylinder Ω),
    ν {x : ProdSpace Ω | ∀ i, x i ∈ C.sets i} =
      ∏ i ∈ C.J, μ i (C.sets i)

/-!
Theorem : Impossibility theorem

If the set $I_\infty = {i\in I : \mu_i(\Omega_i)=\infty}$ is uncountable, then no $\sigma$-finite product measure can exist on $\prod_{i\in I} \Omega_i$.

Suppose, for contradiction, that such a measure $\nu$ exists. By $\sigma$-finiteness we have $\prod_i \Omega_i = \bigcup_{n=1}^\infty B_n$ with $\nu(B_n) < \infty$. Each $B_n$, being an element of the product $\sigma$-algebra, depends on at most countably many coordinates; denote this countable set by $J_n$. The union $J = \bigcup_n J_n$ is still countable. Since $I_\infty$ is uncountable, we can choose an index $i_0 \in I_\infty \setminus J$. Consider the cylinder $C = \Omega_{i_0} \times \prod_{i\neq i_0} \Omega_i$. By the definition of a product measure, $\nu(C) = \mu_{i_0}(\Omega_{i_0}) = \infty$. However, $C$ is covered by the sets $B_n$, each of finite measure, which would force $\nu(C) \le \sum_n \nu(B_n) < \infty$ – a contradiction. Hence no $\sigma$-finite $\nu$ satisfying the product condition can exist.
-/

structure UncountableInfiniteCondition where
  infinite_indices : Set I
  uncountable : ¬ Set.Countable infinite_indices
  has_infinite_measure : ∀ i ∈ infinite_indices, μ i (Set.univ) = ∞

theorem no_sigma_finite_product_uncountable_infinite
    (h : UncountableInfiniteCondition Ω μ) :
    ¬ ∃ (ν : Measure (ProdSpace Ω)), SigmaFinite ν ∧ IsProductProbabilityMeasure Ω μ ν := by
  rintro ⟨ ν, hν₁, hν₂ ⟩;
  obtain ⟨ J, hJ₁, hJ₂ ⟩ := h;
  -- Since $J$ is uncountable, we can choose an index $i_0 \in J$.
  obtain ⟨ i₀, hi₀ ⟩ : ∃ i₀ ∈ J, True := by
    exact Exists.elim ( Set.nonempty_iff_ne_empty.2 ( by rintro rfl; exact hJ₁ <| Set.countable_empty ) ) fun x hx => ⟨ x, hx, trivial ⟩;
  have := hν₂ ⟨ { i₀ }, fun i => Set.univ, fun i => MeasurableSet.univ, fun i hi => rfl ⟩ ; simp_all +decide;
  have := hν₂ ⟨ ∅, fun _ => Set.univ, fun _ => MeasurableSet.univ, fun _ _ => rfl ⟩ ; aesop;

structure ProductMeasureExistenceCondition where
  J : Set I
  J_countable : Set.Countable J
  finite_on_J : ∀ i ∈ J, μ i (Set.univ) < ∞
  probability_outside_J : ∀ i ∉ J, μ i (Set.univ) = 1
  product_converges : ∏ᶠ i ∈ J, μ i (Set.univ) < ∞

theorem product_measure_exists_iff :
    (∃ (ν : Measure (ProdSpace Ω)),
        SigmaFinite ν ∧ IsProductProbabilityMeasure Ω μ ν)
    ↔
    ∃ (h : ProductMeasureExistenceCondition Ω μ), True := by sorry

end InfiniteProductMeasures
